description.text:
This is just a modification from the "Dremel Mount by stiganielsen" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:892963) to fit the Dremel 3000.
The top part have 55mm of diameter.
The bottom part must be downloaded from the original files (from stiganielsen) Notes:
  • because I didn't want to change the bottom part yet, some part of the top part became thin near the flat base so booth rings still concentric. As an update I will need to change booth parts, putting the Dremel farther from the base to avoid this.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,3mm

Infill:

20% honeycomb

Notes: I recommend print it in ABS.

I used the Rhino file available from the source (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:892963) and did the modifications using Rhinoceros 5. As it is a "work in progress", I will make some adjustments latter and maybe upload an updated version of the bottom part also.

description.text:
I was thinking this would make a good prop to go in a candy bowl at Halloween.  I have uploaded 2 versions, a supported and an unsupported. The supports were created in Meshmixer.
UPDATE (13/OCT/2015) :  New models have been uploaded which are the same scale, but the mesh has been reduced greatly so it won't take so long to download.  The one with supports now has fatter posts so they should hold up better during print.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

15%

Notes: If you don't like the Meshmixer supports then use the unsupported version and create your own with your slicer of choice.

I cut, pasted, pushed, and pulled the mesh into submission in Meshmixer. The hat and cane were modeled from primatives in Meshmixer and the arms were added through some stock arms in Meshmixer that I shaped to what I needed. I used this image to work to.

author: Slifer274

description.text: This word clock is based on the NeoMatrix 8x8 Word Clock by Andy Doro from https://learn.adafruit.com/neomatrix-8x8-word-clock. Not having access to a laser cutter to cut the faceplate and case I adapted the design so it could be 3D printed. After building a couple of clocks for friends and family I came to the conclusion that I needed to decrease my parts cost so I adapted the design to use a Rainbowduino and a 8x8 RGB matrix display. This reduced my cost by almost half.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: I printed the clock face and back in Black PLA and the diffusers in either White or Translucent PLA on a Printrbot Simple Metal using 0.2mm layer height and 2 top, bottom and Perimeter Shells. For the clock face I used 50% perimeter overlap and gap fill to keep the light from the NeoPixels from bleeding through the face. For other colors you may want to increase the thickness of the faceplate. The OpenSCAD source is included if you want of need to make any changes.
See the included PDF for build instructions and the WordClock_Rainbow.zip file for the arduino sketch source.

description.text:
Had an old frame lying around and needed some landing gear and there was nothing to choose from here. 
Use 0.157" OD (~4mm) x 4 carbon fiber rod for the shaft. Mount with original hardware.

Rafts:

Supports:

No

15%

Cut carbon rod to desired length (I used 10cm). Sand ends, as the tolerances are quite small. Depending on your printer, you may have to sand quite a bit. You may also need to drill out the hole on the mounting plate, as mine was not exactly round when it came off the printer.
Mount the plate onto the leg, then push the rod in. You can use CA glue to secure them if desired.

title: Actuator Modification for Rockler 4 Inch Stable Gate

description.text: I modified a Universal Power Door Lock Actuator to open and close a Rockler 4 inch Stable gate for a wood shop dust collection system. Included are the parts to do the modifications and mount the actuator to the gate. Remove the dust boot and saw off the top end of the actuator case just below the groove for the dust boot. Pry open the actuator case and remove the large gear and the rack gear/plunger. Use a dremel tool or similar to cut a hole in the bottom of the actuator for the new rack gear/plunger to protrude through. Insert the new plunger and reassemble the actuator. I just put some zip ties around it to hold it together. Install the arm on the plunger, and the mount on the actuator. Align the actuator in its closed position on the side of the gate and glue the mount to the side of the gate. Drill small holes in the gate slide top and use some sheet metal screws to connect the arm to the gate slide. I still need to figure out a method to create a new dust boot. I'm thinking vinyl glove finger or something similar. Video at https://youtu.be/rlGQl_NfcME

comments.text: This is exactly what I have been looking for. I am trying to build a low cost automatic blast gates for my wood shop. Where can I get the gear extenders and arm and how much to they cost?
comments.author: Mgbranm

comments.text: That is pretty nice.. I did something similar in my shop but the wood dust and vacuum from the dust collector preventend the gate from functionning correctly. Hope You have better luck ;-)
comments.author: Rigor_M

comments.text: Thanks for the comment.  These actuators are fairly powerful so I'm hoping they'll do the job.  If they're not, I can always add a second one on the other side of the gate - they're cheap enough.  They're available on eBay at just over $2 each.  The shop they're going in isn't ready yet so they're still untested in a working environment.   I'll update when they're in service.

title: Arm for auto leveling to reuse Z endstop (with gCode)

description.text: Auto bed leveling arm adapter for reuse Z endstop

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes: Just testing for now... I've made this on PLA as a beta until I get a decent ABS printing (my hand made leveling really sucks :P).

It's a modification of the Auto Bed Level arm made by @killcity to reuse the Z endstop instead of adding a new switch, I build this since I had some issues with the switches I bought... Update Oct 8th 2015 I've mounted the new arm with the Z endstop and enable the bed leveling, since the arm is bigger than the original one, I've added some custom extra movements to the Start G-code of my Slic3r configuration: G28 X0 Y0 ;home X & Y
G1 X100 Y100 F5000 ;move nozzle to centre of bed
G28 Z0 ;home Z
G29 ;probe bed
G90; set absolute coordinates
G92 E0; reset extruder distance
G1 Z17 F300 ;move nozzle up 17mm for release arm and avoid colisions with the heating bed, this may vary depending on your nozzle height
M280 P0 S155; my prove position is 57 and retract 15 however, once printing starts, my arm stuck with the heating bed with that retraction angle so I force the arm to go in a safe direction with this move.
G1 X0 Y0 Z0 F5000; move nozzle to home I'm testing right now the Auto Leveling with my second ABS printing and I can tell you that the quality and details have increased compared with my first attempt with the manually leveling.

description.text:
This Soprano size ukulele is a 3 piece design:
  • Body
  • Fretboard
  • Bridge
    • It has a conventional headstock in contrast to my other headless design. It has a groove in the neck to accommodate a neck rod to stiffen it as most 3D printed plastic is too bendy under string tension. Use something like this for the in-neck rod:
  • http://www.acpsales.com/.125-x-.325-Rectangular-Rod.html
    • Also it is meant to be fitted with:
  • simple friction tuners like http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E3UA3JQ
  • simple bridge pins like http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006X0UCKY
    • You can see/hear a demo of it on Youtube https://youtu.be/ooCCqn-EJtk
Open SCAD Scaling spheres, making sure gradient is smooth where parts meet, lots of trigonometry :-)

comments.text: Your demo video made me smile with that happy sound.
comments.author: dz1sfb

comments.text: Sorry I don't understand, the grooves at top of fretboard?  The indentations in Zeroth fret position i.e. the slots on the nut? If they don't align well with strings you may have to widen or deepen the slots with a small file and make the strings sit better in them.  Sorry, not the best solution I know.

description.text:
Just started on my first Prusa i3 build and while there are plenty of options for the Y corners, i designed these with screw down caps for the smooth rods.
I like to design things that use the ability of 3D printers hence the recess on the top of the caps.
Based on the standard 1 X M10 rod ( long front to back) & 2 X M8 cross rods & 8mm OD smooth rods
Each cap needs 2 X M3 x 10mm cap screws ( 15 mm long will work as well).
No trapped nuts needed, just tap the holes M3. As this isnt a high load/stress point so alternatively self tapping screws could be used.
Corner cap for SC8VUU bearings ( bearing and housing
Corner cap LP version ( low profile) for standard LM8UU linear bearings
If you like this thing .....hit the button

description.text:
This is the Humpty Lock that Hinamori Amu wears in the anime Shugo Chara.
.
The hearts should help keep the setting from warping. Simply cut them off and paint as needed and then glue it all together.
.
A little filing may be necessary to get the hearts to fit properly. I had to file the V section of the heart for it to fit.
.
After which I primed all the parts, the hearts did not print out smooth so I use some glazing putty to fill in the grooves and then re-primed.
.
My daughter then painted the lock and setting gold, and the hearts were painted with a white base coat followed up with a top coat of glitter paint.
.
I still need to put on a glossy clear coat for protection but so far it is coming along nicely.

comments.text: I loved this show, and this model is fantastic! Can't wait to print it.
comments.author: JacobVe

comments.text: The hearts will require some filing and finishing touches. I made this for my daughter and she loved it. :)

remixed_from.title: Cooling fan ducts for Monkeyfab Prime3D (Budaschnozzle)

title: Cooling fan ducts for Monkeyfab Prime3D (Bullet)

description.text:
Cooling system for Monkeyfab Prime3D printer. Designed for two, 40 mm fans. It greatly improves quality of printouts then good cooling is necessary (especially when printing models with bridges and overhangs). It is designed to work with new Bullet hotend. If you have Budaschnozzle hotend, see the previous version. For test models see the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:796956. There is also an remix for lama hotend - see Universal fan duct cooling for lama hotend For more information visit my blog (Polish):
http://3dwpraktyce.pl/2015/11/chlodzenie-wydruku-z-hotendem-bullet/
http://3dwpraktyce.pl/2015/03/nowe-rozwiazanie-do-chlodzenia-wydrukow/

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes: Because the mount and both ducts are close to a hotend, printing them with ABS is a good choice.

The mount item contains 2 little supports at front - remove them after printing.  
To fix ducts to the mount element you will need two screws (about 4x20 mm). To fix the mount to printer itself you can reuse screws from original cooling duct.
For better results you may use a piece of PTFE (teflon) as a hotend shield. It can be bought in small sheets (1 mm thick one is OK). The printed plate template will help you in cutting PTFE properly.

description.text: Housing / bezel for Maker Base MKS-TFT Touch Screen Controller, available direct from Maker Base on AliExpress or a few eBay sellers. It is a very snug fit with only 0.1 mm clearance all around the board. This was designed to go on the Eustathios Spider v2 https://github.com/eclsnowman/Eustathios-Spider-V2 IGES and STEP files are included so you may modify the design for your own needs.

Notes: Printed with whatever you have handy. Printing face down should eliminate the need for any support. The USB, SD and 12v power ports all have knockouts that fill the holes if not used. If your printer prints slightly undersized scale up in your slicer. The internal board mounts with M3 screws. If you use M3 brass heat set inserts (McMaster 94180A331) you will need to drill out the holes larger.

i posted it here http://www.instructables.com/id/Aluminum-Extrution-3d-printer-with-12x12-inch-heat/
all stl files are what i found around the net and many were used for the printer, i however did not design them,just wanted to share what i used

Here's a set of v-groove bearing covers that press-fit over standard size bearings.  The SCAD is parameterized so to fit other size bearings (or even just a hole instead of a bear).  
I've included STLs for some standard size bearings, although you will likely have to adjust the tolerance variable in the SCAD file to get a good tight fit.  If all else fails you might try heating the bearing then press-fitting with a pliers.  PLA is no match for a hot bearing. :-)  
These are probably reasonable stand-ins for metal vgroove bearings for a light duty application (e.g. a string pulley or a mockup).  It would not be appropriate to use it for anything weight-bearing.

This hot end is the result of my attempt to build the Wildseyed Simple Hot End by jcabrer for my Simpler repstrap.  I live in Metric land, along with the ROW (rest of the world) which started my journey down the path less taken to begin with...
I noticed that it would be possible to use the previously unused M6 thread on the MIG tip to our advantage, and make the tip itself easily exchangeable.  This design also makes the fitting of the PTFE easier and more precisely aligned than I could manage on Wildseyed, with the unexpected bonus of a double seal on the PTFE rod.
Using the gas connector nipple also gives a flat face for the heater, making working with nichrome a bit easier, giving you a choice of heater technology.
Note that this hot end is very definitely a work in progress, and that the instructions will be updated as I go along.

Thread adapter nipple (Air Hose connector):
1) Push the adapter into the drill press chuck - tip first, and tighten slightly.
2) Lower the drill press and securely clamp the adapter on its base in the drill press vice.
3) Release the Chuck from the adapter, and insert 8mm drill bit.
4) Carefully increase the inner diameter of the adapter shaft, all the way through.
5) Remove the adapter from the drill press, and using the hacksaw, cut the adapter in the middle of the narrow sectoin of the shaft, as per the CAD drawing.
6) File the cut neat and flat. MIG Welding tip:
1) Lightly clamp the welding tip into the drill press chuck, with the tip pointing downwards.
2) Similar to the adapter, clamp the MIG tip in the drill press vice, making use of the flat faces on the tip.
3) Insert the 3.2mm drill bit, and using cutting oil, carefully cut exactly 25mm into the back of the MIG tip.
4) Make sure to remove all the metal filings and cutting oil from the tip. PTFE (Teflon) shaft:
1) Clamp a piece of scrap wood in the drill press vice.
2) Using the 3.2mm drill bit still attached to the machine, drill about 15mm into the piece of wood.
3) Remove the bit from the chuck and insert into the hole in the wood.
4) Insert the 1/2inch (12.7mm) PTFE rod into the drill press chuck, making sure to insert it deep into the chuck, and using just enough force to clamp it tightly.
5) Hold the drill bit with a long nose plier while drilling into the PTFE with the stationary drill bit. If your bit is not long enough, turn the PTFE shaft around, and drill from the other side to go all the way though.
6) The 3.2mm hole though the shaft should match nicely.
7) Using a 4.5mm drill bit drill 8mm into the 3.2mm hole. You can do this by hand - it is always nicely centered.
8) Using the drill press, and a knife or chisel, work the end with the 4.5mm hole down to 12mm (or less) to make it turn easily into the Air hose, but do not turn it in yet. Assembling the parts:
1) Tap the MIG tip with the hammer into the enlarged tip of the adapter. It will be a tight but not necessarily press fitted match. Keep going until the base of the tip aligns with the inside of the large diameter threaded section of the adapter.
2) Insert the 3.2mm drill bit into the back of the MIG tip, with the cutting side first. This will allow us to use the shaft as a guide pin when turning the PTFE rod onto the threaded sections of the adapter and the MIG tip.
3) Turn the Rod into the adapter, allowing the adapter threads and the MIG tip to cut its own threads on the outer and inner sides of the PTFE. It should be tight, but easy enough to turn to feel when you reach the end of travel.
4) Unscrew the PTFE rod to reveal your newly cut thread, and remove the drill bit.
5) carefully screw the PTFE rod back on the thread, and check the alignment of the inner channel. It should now be easy to insert the drill bit into the back right into the copper section.
6) OPTIONAL: Use a countersunk tip to manually slightly countersunk the back end of the 3.2mm hole in the PTFE to ease filament insertion.

A bearing with the same form factor as the 608 which uses 3mm-lengths of 2mm filament as rollers.  A more refined version of my previous one, it actually has slightly MORE friction, but much better tolerances -- I'd estimate 0.5mm thrust and wobble.  Careful sanding and cleaning might reduce that more.

Your ability to make this work will depend on your ability to cut and manipulate dozens of tiny rollers out of ABS filament. Fill each of the holes on the jig with slightly more filament than needed then sand them flat. This is NOT a waste of time! Pointy rollers vs flat ones is the difference between a bearing that goes crunch vs one that goes whirr.  If it goes clatter, you may not have put enough rollers in it, leaving a big gap inside.  
Depending on the tolerances of your printer, the jig may be slightly too short or tall. Scale as appropriate.  
Stick maybe 2 dozen on a piece of scotch tape, and curl it around the inside of the tall large piece. Insert the tall core, and add more rollers until it's full. Glue on the short large piece with ABS cement, carefully remove the tape with needlenose pliers, glue on the short center piece.  
Weigh down the center piece with something while the glue sets.  You want it relatively tight.  
A drop of oil inside goes a long way.

author: krig

description.text:
This is the second revision of my workshop stool. It is made out of 1/2" MDF and is press fit together. It was designed in SketchUp and cut out on a ShopBot. improvements since v1
  • 3 legs (instead of 4) to increase stability on uneven flooring
  • bottom ring to reduce wobble
  • 1/32" tolerance for joints to make assembly easier
  • less wasted material (fits on 2'x4' sheet)

1) use the provided DXF file to cut out a 2' x 4' x 1/2" sheet of MDF (or plywood) on your favorite CNC router.
2) sand all parts until you're happy with them.
3) slip the legs into the bottom (larger) ring.
4) seat (smaller circle) should push down onto leg nubs.

description.text:
The carpal tunnel splint is a simple 3d printable wrist flexion resisting brace which is minimal and contoured to the shape of the forearm, wrist, and palm. If you suffer from carpal tunnel syndrome this splint will prevent you from flexing your wrist forward whilst being minimalist at the same time. Unlike the bulky chemist bought ones. The design is being 'clinically' trailed on my mum who suffers from carpal pain. Update 2.2
Version 2.2 has been uploaded and is now available for download. There are 2 models, one for the right hand and one for the left: both mirror images of each other, specified by an R and an L. The method of designing this model was slightly primitive and unconventional but it allowed me to achieve a naturally contoured shape that fits the wrist beautifully.
The next update will include possible mesh or webbing iterations of the current models as well as rounded edges plus a slot/clip for Velcro attachment.
Hope you enjoy!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

I used 0.25 due to the lack of need for detail.

Infill:

Solid infill.

Notes: The model as is in the stl file is not oriented yet. I personally oriented the model diagonally on its edge due to the limited print base area of my UP mini. Although I have not yet uploaded an image of the printed product I have printed it successfully. Done at 0.25mm z-resolution in ABS at normal quality as it was only a draft.
Pending images This model is a slightly modified version of a previous prototype in that the forearm brace has been slightly extended upward to reduce irritation.

Process of development I was inspired to design this by my mum who occasionally suffers from carpal tunnel syndrome pain in her right hand. Model 2.2 of the CTS (carpal tunnel splint) was designed from paper. I folded the paper in half and used scissors to shape the outline. I then extended the halves at right angle and placed it on my wrist. Fine tuning the edge until the perfect contours were achieved. A photograph was then taken of the flattened paper and imported into sketchup where the outline was traced. The two halves were then rotated so that they were oriented at 90° to one another. This have the basic outline which then allowed me to complete the ends of the model and extrude it vertically.

title: LM8LUU Bearing Blocks for Prusa Y-Axis

description.text:
Designed some blocks to mount the longer LM8LUU (8x15x45mm) linear bearings onto the Prusa i3 aluminum Y-carriage.
This is designed with two M3 recessed screw holes spaced 20mm apart, with a key that fits in the hole where the original bearings were tied to.
If your Y-carriage doesn't have that hole, but still has 20mm spacing for the screws, you can comment out a block of text in the .SCAD to remove the key.
Requires 4x 10mm M3 screws and washers to retain the bearings, and 2x 20mm-30mm M3 socket head cap screws to screw the blocks to the Y-carriage. 20mm are long enough if your plate is threaded - use 25-30mm with nuts if yours is drilled through.

This design contains two versions in one STL file. You can remove the one you do not want in your slicer. The basic difference between the two is that one of them uses two pieces while the other one is one piece. Both versions are designed to hold a Nano Tech 3S 1300Mah LIPO and the XT60 connector from your PDB. I designed the parts for the ZMR 250 arm plate and not the traditional top plate that comes with the ZMR 250. My ZMR 250 quad utilizes just two arm plates. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6UtcHb0yFku

I designed these arm mounts so that the ZMR 250 arms can tilt 10 degrees inwards towards the frame, unlike motor mounts that tilt the motors 10 degrees forward. In my setup, I mounted the arms underneath the arm plate but you can mount the arms above as well by placing the mount in between the arm and the plate. You can still utilize the screws that come with the ZMR 250 frame. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eIQ8WqBlmC5

Notes: Should be printed in ABS due to heat. Connecting the led strips;
Solder the strips in parallel and connect it to your 12V power supply, make sure the polarity of the strips is correct! Then zip-tie the LED-strip to the bracket. Assembly;
The tight fit should provide enough hold, making the parts fit nicely together. However, depending on your printer's accuracy, you may need to glue the two pieces together. Also included the SketchUp file if adjustment is needed.

title: Split-Body Project Enclosures (Seven sizes)

description.text:
A relatively perfect box for your electronics projects. Print two copies of any size, add any four ~3mm countersink screws, and enjoy a professional-like project enclosure for any of your DIY needs. You can manually drill out the front and back plates to accommodate switches, displays, and the like. Alternatively, you can import any file into your favorite 3D editor to quickly cut the holes you need before you print for cleaner results and faster print times. Sizes currently available (mm; X, Y, Z; first three pictured):
  • 60x95x25 (mint tin sized)
  • 60x95x45
  • 85x95x45
  • 85x130x45
  • 120x130x45
  • 120x130x65

These boxes were designed with respectable tolerances. If you happen to find any gaps in the finished boxes, consider filing down any bumps or blobs on the case halves and their end caps. Alternatively, tuning your printer for slightly slower speeds may also help. 
Any four roughly 3mm diameter screws will work. Countersunk heads will work best. You should also use (or cut) screws no longer then 6mm to avoid catching any electronics inside.

title: Vacuum Station Base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Inspired by something so simple, I couldn't believe it. I backed his project because I wanted one and if the project updates weren't convincing enough, I went and derived my very own for proof-of-concept. The project is currently live as of June 18, 2013 and my inspiration can be found at: http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1066541019/thriftyvac This is really a proof-of-concept. If you like what you see, back his project to show support. 6/19/13 Update: Separate file for top and bottom and corrected top piece so single round corner actually goes into impression.

Once printed, do the following: -place the smaller piece on top of the larger piece fitting where the impressions are
-acquire a
--Vacuum Pump
--Check Valve
--Big enough bag to house a smaller bag to vacuum seal
--Test item like a cut in half lemon
-Poke a hole in the big bag where the vacuum station will go when it is inside the big bag
-plug the check valve into the hole so that the big bag is between the check valve and vacuum station base. Once the air has been vacuum out of both bags, seal the inner bag. It really helps to have the inner bag partially sealed and with the opening on top of the rounded corner square. The hole is about 3mm in diameter to accommodate the check valve insert. Make sure to get sealable bags that have double zippers. Sliders could work but have read they aren't so great. Experiment! Vacuum pump, check valve can be located on the big selection dot com online retailer. If you like what you see, support his awesome KS project!

title: Manfrotto Expan Metal Chain Weight Holder

description.text:
This replaces the weight holder for the Manfrotto Expan Plastic chain, so that it works with the metal chain. The weight holder for the plastic chain doesn't fit the metal chain, and there is no replacement, so you are left with the choice of a plastic chain that breaks or a metal chain that gets tangled. 
Note: you need the original metal weight, and a nut and bolt to secure it to the weight holder. I tried making one with little nubs to mimic the original weight but it was too difficult to get the weight on with the 3d printed material I used (ABS plastic).
